Key Arguments: The legislation represents collusion between the government and tech companies to censor public debate.
The bill is seen as an attempt to establish a 'Ministry of Truth' to suppress views opposing the Labor party.
Concerns about the concentration of power in ACMA to determine 'truth' and 'harm' in public debate.
Skepticism about the government's ability to remain impartial and apolitical in suppressing information.
Existing laws already address defamation and incitement to violence, making the bill unnecessary.
The bill is viewed as an elitist move that undermines the public's right to free argument and debate.
Main Themes: Existing legal frameworks for defamation and incitement
Notable Quotes: This Bill formalises the collusion of Big Government and Big Tech in the censorship of public debate.
A handful of government employees at ACMA will have the unchallengeable authority to determine ‘truth’ and judge ‘harm’ on any matter of public debate.
This Bill is a disgraceful abuse of Government power and an assault on the liberty of a free self-governing democracy.
